title: A Unified Speech LLM for Diarization and Speech Recognition in Multilingual Conversations
author: Phurich Saengthong (Institute of Science Tokyo), Boonnithi Jiaramaneepinit (Institute of Science Tokyo), Sheng Li (Institute of Science Tokyo), Manabu Okumura (Institute of Science Tokyo), Takahiro Shinozaki (Institute of Science Tokyo)
relevance_why: The techniques discussed for joint speaker diarization and automatic speech recognition (ASR) may provide insights into multimodal integration and could inform improvements in audio-text alignment tasks relevant to Haohe's research.
background: This paper presents a new model for speech recognition that can simultaneously identify speakers and transcribe what they are saying in multilingual conversations.
contribution: This paper introduces a unified speech Large Language Model (LLM) that performs diarization and ASR simultaneously, achieving a 54.87% relative improvement in transcription and recognition accuracy.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods separate the tasks of diarization and recognition, which often leads to loss of context and inaccuracies in speaker assignment.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work integrates these processes into a single model, allowing for context-aware predictions that resolve ambiguities more effectively.

key_innovation: Utilizes a novel locally sliding inference window combined with prompt-based context to enhance the prediction of speaker identity and speech content.
real_world_impact: Improving the accuracy and fluency of speech recognition systems in diverse real-time multilingual settings could significantly enhance communication tools and services.
limitations: The model may still exhibit discrepancies in speaker assignments across longer conversations due to local context limitations.

new_terms.tcpWER: **Transcription Character Error Rate** is a metric for assessing transcription accuracy by measuring the character errors in the output compared to the reference.
new_terms.Diarization Error Rate (DER): **Diarization Error Rate (DER)** is a measure of how accurately a system can segment and label speakers in a given audio.
new_terms.Local Diarization and Recognition: **Local Diarization and Recognition** refers to a method where each speaker's turns are identified and transcribed using local context rather than analyzing the full conversation.
